awd_titl_txt: Advancing archaeological synthesis through the digitization and interoperability of ceramic data
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This award was provided as part of NSF’s Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Kostalena Michelaki-Schwartz at Arizona State University and Dr. Andrea Berlin at Boston University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist seeking to revolutionize the publication and accessibility of ceramic data. This research will both advance the theory and method of archaeology and create a common tool for the dissemination and interoperability of data related to ceramic manufacture from the advent of pottery through the Historic Period—the Pan-American Archaeological Ceramic Database (PAACD). This open-access, digital repository will provide the general public and archaeologists with a virtual resource of curated reference materials. By eliminating the complications of gaining access to physical collections and paywalled publications, or deciphering inconsistent terminology across languages, this project will increase the breadth, depth, and speed of research, and facilitate the inclusion of prehistoric material culture in educational resources. 

Inspiration for the PAACD derives from the Fellow’s own research on the influence of social identification and collective action on the growth and decline of Epiclassic (600-900 CE) polities. Determining how closely these polities interacted and what forms their interactions took is currently hampered by a lack of regional-scale datasets. Therefore, building upon her previous research, the Fellow will complete an integrated database of ceramic types and attributes that will allow for synthetic research to be conducted. Thus, it offers an ideal foundation upon which to construct the PAACD. This work involves: (1) review and verify the existing attribute data on 238 types from 15 sites and one survey area and collect data from seven new collections; (2) conduct a technological analysis of a ceramic assemblage; and (3) integrate ceramic attribute data using the software and ontological framework of the Digital Archaeological Record (tDAR.org). The subsequent design and development of the PAACD will then involve consultation with a network of experts in ceramic technology and compositional methods that the Fellow has curated, as well as key stakeholders to ensure the functionality of the PAACD for all potential users. Several workshops will be organized to introduce the website to potential contributors and/or provide opportunities for mass data uploads to the site. The digital infrastructure of comparable and accessible data within the PAACD should be implemented in other regions of the world and replicated across other social science disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Pottery situates people in time and space, reveals past communities, and illuminates past lives. It is an indispensable form of archaeological evidence as well as a material link between past and present. However, our understanding of regional-scale social phenomena, such as the ability of communities to persevere, transform, or collapse, requires a synthetic approach to archaeological research that is only possible when data are Findable, Accessible, Interoperable (i.e., comparable), and Reusable (i.e. the FAIR principles of scientific research), as well as treated with CARE (i.e., for Collective benefit, giving Indigenous communities Authority to control their data, Responsibility to engage Indigenous communities respectfully about their data, and engaging Indigenous Ethics to minimize harm and promote justice). As such, a major goal of this project was the creation of a community-based digital product aimed at increasing the accessibility and reusability of information related to the entire manufacturing process and the function of archaeological ceramics from across the Americas to foster synthetic research across communities, borders, and specialties. 

Our goal was achieved in December 2022 with the launch of the Pan-American Ceramics Project, or PACP, as an open-access web application designed to make ceramic data available at a continental scale, facilitate collaboration within and across countries, and reveal lacunae in existing data. Through time, the PACP will generate, facilitate, and galvanize research and curation among a growing collaborative network of scholars, curators, students, and Indigenous, descendent, and local community stakeholders across international borders via an open-access, expandable repository for data on pottery from Canada to Argentina over its 7,500-year history. It is also a portal for information that anybody can access, and to which anybody can submit information relevant to pottery, its context, manufacture, and movements, including photos, drawings, maps, descriptions of wares, types, forms, pastes, and techniques. 

At present, three months after its first update in August 2023, the PACP already includes information on 100 wares, 334 types, 856 vessels, 4 petro-fabrics, 9 thin sections, 6 sites, 435 bibliographic references, and 19 registered contributors. Between October 19 and November 15, 2023, the site has engaged 70 new users, according to Google Analytics.

Access to a virtual resource of material culture that is housed in difficult to access collections, repositories, and laboratories is equally important for researchers with physical or financial barriers and Indigenous communities who have been forcibly removed from their ancestral lands. Furthermore, the PACP offers a path toward an equitable and inclusive resource that will accommodate and welcome the voices of multiple stakeholders and eventually grant data sovereignty to different rights holders. From initial design through iterative development, we are building a dynamic structure alongside and with the input of a wide community seeking to create an open-access resource for pottery in the Americas. With NSF support we have begun to build a community focused on the development and growth of the PACP as a tool for collaboration and communication. This has involved recruiting colleagues to join our Traditional Knowledge Network and Advisory Board that will help guide the future growth of the PACP in ways consistent with the FAIR and CARE principles, as well as mentoring twelve undergraduate students on how to ethically source, organize, and publish archaeological data.
